PannerNode.summary: The PannerNode interface defines an audio-processing object that represents the location, direction, and behavior of an audio source signal in a simulated physical space. This uses right-hand Cartesian coordinates to describe the source's position as a vector and its orientation as a 3D directional cone.

remarks.para: A PannerNode always has exactly one input and one output: the input can be mono or stereo but the output is always stereo (2 channels); you can't have panning effects without at least two audio channels!

para.see: The PannerNode defines a spatial position and direction for a given signal.

remarks.para: -Using the Web Audio API

PannerNodeRolloffFactor.summary: The rolloffFactor property of the interface is a double value describing how quickly the volume is reduced as the source moves away from the listener. This value is used by all distance models. The rolloffFactor property's default value is 1.

remarks.para:
-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics

PannerNodeRolloffFactor.value: A number whose range depends on the of the panner as follows (negative values are not allowed):

summary.blockquote: NOTEThe suggested replacement for this deprecated method is to instead set the positionX, positionY, and positionZ attributes directly.

remarks.para: The setPosition() method of the Interface defines the position of the audio source relative to the listener (represented by an object stored in the attribute.) The three parameters x, y and z are unitless and describe the source's position in 3D space using the right-hand Cartesian coordinate system.
The setPosition() method's default value of the position is (0, 0, 0).
-Using the Web Audio API

PannerNodePositionX.summary:
The positionX property of the interface specifies the X coordinate of the audio source's position in 3D Cartesian
coordinates, corresponding to the horizontal axis (left-right).

remarks.para:
The complete vector is defined by the position of the audio source, given as
(positionX, ,
), and the orientation
of the audio source (that is, the direction in which it's facing), given as
(,
,
).

Depending on the directionality of the sound (as specified using the attributes
,
, and
), the orientation of the
sound may alter the perceived volume of the sound as it's being played. If the sound
is pointing toward the listener, it will be louder than if the sound is pointed away
from the listener.

The contained by this property is read only; however, you
can still change the value of the parameter by assigning a new value to its
property.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics
-

PannerNodePositionX.value:
An whose value is the X coordinate of the audio
source's position, in 3D Cartesian coordinates. The default value is 0.

The orientationX property of the interface indicates the X (horizontal) component of the
direction in which the audio source is facing, in a 3D Cartesian coordinate space.

remarks.para:
The complete vector is defined by the position of the audio source, given as
(, ,

of the audio source (that is, the direction in which it's facing), given as
(orientationX,

Depending on the directionality of the sound (as specified using the attributes

), the orientation of the
sound may alter the perceived volume of the sound as it's being played. If the sound
is pointing toward the listener, it will be louder than if the sound is pointed away
from the listener.

The contained by this property is read only; however, you
can still change the value of the parameter by assigning a new value to its
property.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics

PannerNodeOrientationX.value:
An whose value is the X component of the
direction in which the audio source is facing, in 3D Cartesian coordinate space.

Depending on the directionality of the sound (as specified using the attributes

PannerNodePannerNode.summary: The PannerNode() constructor of the Web Audio API creates a new object instance.

PannerNodeDistanceModel.summary: The distanceModel property of the interface is an enumerated value determining which algorithm to use to reduce the volume of the audio source as it moves away from the listener.

remarks.para: The possible values are:
inverse is the default value of distanceModel.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics

PannerNodeConeInnerAngle.summary: The coneInnerAngle property of the interface is a double value describing the angle, in degrees, of a cone inside of which there will be no volume reduction.

remarks.para: The coneInnerAngle property's default value is 360, suitable for a non-directional source.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics

PannerNodeConeOuterAngle.summary: The coneOuterAngle property of the interface is a double value describing the angle, in degrees, of a cone outside of which the volume will be reduced by a constant value, defined by the property.

remarks.para: The coneOuterAngle property's default value is 0.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics

PannerNodeOrientationY.summary:
The orientationY property of the interface
indicates the Y (vertical) component of the direction the audio source is facing, in 3D Cartesian coordinate space.

remarks.para:
The complete vector is defined by the position of the audio source, given as
(, ,
), and the orientation
of the audio source (that is, the direction in which it's facing), given as
(,
orientationY,
).

Depending on the directionality of the sound (as specified using the attributes
,
, and
), the orientation of the
sound may alter the perceived volume of the sound as it's being played. If the sound
is pointing toward the listener, it will be louder than if the sound is pointed away
from the listener.

The contained by this property is read only; however, you
can still change the value of the parameter by assigning a new value to its
property.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics
-

PannerNodeOrientationY.value:
An whose value is the Y component of the
direction the audio source is facing, in 3D Cartesian coordinate space.

summary.blockquote: NOTEThe suggested replacement for this deprecated method is to instead set the orientationX, orientationY, and orientationZ attributes directly.

remarks.para: The setOrientation() method of the Interface defines the direction the audio source is playing in.

This can have a big effect if the sound is very directional — controlled by the three cone-related attributes , , and . In such a case, a sound pointing away from the listener can be very quiet or even silent.
The three parameters x, y and z are unitless and describe a direction vector in 3D space using the right-hand Cartesian coordinate system. The default value of the direction vector is (1, 0, 0).
-Using the Web Audio API

PannerNodeRefDistance.summary: The refDistance property of the interface is a double value representing the reference distance for reducing volume as the audio source moves further from the listener – i.e., the distance at which the volume reduction starts taking effect. This value is used by all distance models.

remarks.para: The refDistance property's default value is 1.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics

PannerNodeRefDistance.value: A non-negative number. If the value is set to less than 0, a is thrown.

PannerNodePositionZ.summary:
The positionZ property of the interface specifies the Z coordinate of the audio source's position in 3D Cartesian
coordinates, corresponding to the depth axis (behind-in front of the
listener). The complete vector is defined by the position of the audio source, given
as (,
,
positionZ),
and the orientation of the audio source (that is, the direction in
which it's facing), given as (,
,
).

remarks.para:
Depending on the directionality of the sound (as specified using the attributes
,
, and
), the orientation of the
sound may alter the perceived volume of the sound as it's being played. If the sound
is pointing toward the listener, it will be louder than if the sound is pointed away
from the listener.

The contained by this property is read only; however, you
can still change the value of the parameter by assigning a new value to its
property.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics
-

PannerNodePositionZ.value:
An whose value is the Z coordinate of the audio
source's position, in 3D Cartesian coordinates.

PannerNodePanningModel.summary: The panningModel property of the interface is an enumerated value determining which spatialization algorithm to use to position the audio in 3D space.

remarks.para: The possible values are:
-Using the Web Audio API

PannerNodeConeOuterGain.summary: The coneOuterGain property of the interface is a double value, describing the amount of volume reduction outside the cone, defined by the attribute.

remarks.para: The coneOuterGain property's default value is 0, meaning that no sound can be heard outside the cone.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics

PannerNodeConeOuterGain.value: A double. The default is 0, and its value can be in the range 0–1.

PannerNodeMaxDistance.summary: The maxDistance property of the interface is a double value representing the maximum distance between the audio source and the listener, after which the volume is not reduced any further. This value is used only by the linear distance model.

remarks.para: The maxDistance property's default value is 10000.
-Using the Web Audio API

PannerNodeMaxDistance.value: A double. The default is 10000, and non-positive values are not allowed.

PannerNodePositionY.summary:
The positionY property of the interface specifies the Y coordinate of the audio source's position in 3D Cartesian
coordinates, corresponding to the vertical axis (top-bottom). The complete
vector is defined by the position of the audio source, given as
(, positionY, ), and the orientation
of the audio source (that is, the direction in which it's facing), given as
(,

remarks.para:

, and
), the orientation of the

is pointing toward the listener, it will be louder than if the sound is pointed away
from the listener.

The contained by this property is read only; however, you
can still change the value of the parameter by assigning a new value to its
property.

-Using the Web Audio API
-Web Audio spatialization basics

An whose value is the Y coordinate of the audio
source's position, in 3D Cartesian coordinates.
